course_title: Contemporary Theories of Film and Television

learning_outcomes.description: Understand the development and relationship of distinct disciplinary approaches to studying motion pictures as art.
Use the terms, concepts, and arguments of a particular scholarly approach to develop original claims and analyses.
Critically evaluate pieces of scholarly writing to demonstrate understanding of different perspectives and approaches and their potential merits, constraints, and flaws.
Demonstrate understanding of the fundamental attributes of and issues related to aesthetic criticism and evaluation and apply such understanding to set films.
Demonstrate capacity to produce original criticism and develop one’s own critical voice.

assessments.task_description:
The purpose of this piece of assessment is to have you weigh the merits, constraints, and flaws of a piece of academic writing about one of the set screenings from the first four weeks of class. You are being asked to produce an essayistic annotation of one of the case study readings that is in some way related to one of the set screenings.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
You are required to write a piece of criticism that demonstrates your strengths in the evaluation of film. Some essay suggestions will be released mid-way through the semester, and you may wish to consult with the course coordinator about designing your own essay topic.

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The aim of the writing tasks is to give you frequent opportunities to practice writing analyses that weave together objective features of the week’s set screenings with a particular point or claim you would like to make about them. The questions will differ week-to-week but assess the same set of skills.


This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.
assessments.additional_info: You cannot defer or apply for an extension for this assessment.

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK ONE: Aesthetic Criticism

This week we will explore the following questions: What is aesthetic criticism? What is the value of criticism? How do we try to make objective claims about artworks and their aesthetic value? What is the role of judgment? What do we focus on when we “do” aesthetic criticism? What weight do aesthetic judgements and evaluations carry (why might they matter)?


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: WEEK ONE: Aesthetic Criticism This week we will explore the following questions: What is aesthetic criticism? What is the value of criticism? How do we try to make objective claims about artworks and their aesthetic value? What is the role of judgment? What do we focus on when we “do” aesthetic criticism? What weight do aesthetic judgements and evaluations carry (why might they matter)?

learning_activities.topic: WEEK ONE: NO TUTORIALS
learning_activities.topic_description: WEEK ONE: NO TUTORIALS

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK TWO: Subjectivity, Preference, Taste

This week we will explore the following questions: How do claims about the objective qualities of art involve the subjectivity of the critic? What is the role of selection? Are the so-called subjective and objective opposed, or do they inform each other? How do we choose the “right” language to write about art, and what does that say about us as individual critics?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: WEEK TWO: Subjectivity, Preference, Taste This week we will explore the following questions: How do claims about the objective qualities of art involve the subjectivity of the critic? What is the role of selection? Are the so-called subjective and objective opposed, or do they inform each other? How do we choose the “right” language to write about art, and what does that say about us as individual critics?

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK THREE: Obstacles in Language and Criticism

This week we will explore the following questions: How do we meet the challenge of translating experiential, audio-visual, tactile art into language? What is it we are actually trying to describe in aesthetic criticism? How is it that we can use language to conjure the experience of cinema? In what way does aesthetic criticism’s translation of experience work to cohere together the objective and subjective dimensions of our engagement with art?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK FOUR: Badness and Negative Evaluations

This week we will explore the following questions: How is that we can make claims about the aesthetic flaws of artworks? How is it that we develop and justify the critical criteria against which we evaluate works of art? Why do we value the values that inform our aesthetic judgements about art? How do different clusters of critical criteria illustrate the subjective dimensions of our experience and engagement with art?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

How do different clusters of critical criteria illustrate the subjective dimensions of our experience and engagement with art?

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK SIX: Beauty

This week we will explore the following questions: What is beauty in the context of art? Why do we value beauty? Are there ways in which art can complicate our notions of beauty, and if so, how? How does beauty as a concept work to invoke other aesthetic qualities? 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: WEEK SIX: Beauty This week we will explore the following questions: What is beauty in the context of art? Why do we value beauty? Are there ways in which art can complicate our notions of beauty, and if so, how? How does beauty as a concept work to invoke other aesthetic qualities?

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK SEVEN: Mood and Atmosphere

This week we will explore the following questions: What is mood or atmosphere in the context of art? How is it that films can be said to have a mood or atmosphere? In what ways do we identify mood/atmosphere in particular films? How do we articulate this in language, and why might they be aesthetically valuable aesthetic qualities?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: WEEK SEVEN: Mood and Atmosphere This week we will explore the following questions: What is mood or atmosphere in the context of art? How is it that films can be said to have a mood or atmosphere? In what ways do we identify mood/atmosphere in particular films? How do we articulate this in language, and why might they be aesthetically valuable aesthetic qualities?

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK EIGHT: Tactility and Feeling

This week we will explore the following questions: What is the difference between mood/atmosphere and tactility/feeling? What is it for films to have a particular tactile quality or feeling? How can films evoke tactile responses in spectators? In what ways can films deliberately amplify the artform’s concern with textures and surfaces, and the felt qualities of experience?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03
learning_activities.topic_description: WEEK EIGHT: Tactility and Feeling This week we will explore the following questions: What is the difference between mood/atmosphere and tactility/feeling? What is it for films to have a particular tactile quality or feeling? How can films evoke tactile responses in spectators? In what ways can films deliberately amplify the artform’s concern with textures and surfaces, and the felt qualities of experience?

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK NINE: Rhythm and Pacing

This week we will explore the following questions: In what ways do we identify the stylistic and formal underpinnings of a film’s rhythm and pacing? What is it for a film to have “good” rhythm and “good” pacing? How does this flow into other attributes and aesthetic qualities of a particular film? How do we make an evaluative case for rhythm and pacing?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

How do we make an evaluative case for rhythm and pacing?

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK ELEVEN: Metacinema and Intermediality

GUEST LECTURE: Keya Makar

This week we will explore the following questions: How does the self-reference and reflexivity of films play into their aesthetic value? Likewise, how can a film’s deliberate reference to and invocation of other artforms complicate and expand the means by which we make evaluative judgments about their aesthetic value? To what extent does this uniquely rely on spectator knowledge of different frames of reference? 

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK TWELVE: Violence and the Grotesque: Southern Gothic Cinema

This week we will explore the following questions: In what ways does the depiction of violence problematise our evaluative judgements? In what ways are ethical issues related to the representation of violence a factor that requires our critical attention? How expansive is violence as a concept in the ways in which it is examined in art? How do we evaluate particular instances of broader artistic categories?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

learning_activities.topic:
WEEK THIRTEEN: Feminist Aesthetics

GUEST LECTURE: Dr Bonnie Evans

This week we will explore the following questions: In what ways can theoretical perspectives such as feminism complicate aesthetic criticism? Do such perspectives undermine or undercut the interests of aesthetic criticism? Can they be fruitfully combined? Do theoretical perspectives enable a productive expansion of the interests and values of aesthetic criticism?

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03

Do theoretical perspectives enable a productive expansion of the interests and values of aesthetic criticism?
